pull_request.body:
## Preface

This PR is part of the plan discussed in #236 

- [x] decouple light-service from I18n #238
  - [x] preserve a basic translation functionality #238
  - [x] do not break compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n #238
- [x] strip out LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter into its own light_service-i18n gem #239
  - [x] require gem installation to retain full compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n #239
- [x] decouple light-service from ActiveSupport::Deprecation
  - [x] preserve full functionality through the use of a simple custom logger built on top of `Logger`
- [ ] decouple light-service from ActiveSupport::Inflector
  - [ ] write a LightService::Inflector class responding only to the needed inflection methods (probably #underscore and #pluralize)
  - [ ] LightService::Inflector will delegate its capabilities to dry-inflector (which is a zero-deps gem)
- [ ] strip out LightService::Generators into its own light_service-rails gem
- [ ] release light-service 1.0
  - [ ] shut out upgrade instructions in changelog, requiring installation of new detached gems in order to retain moved functionalities (in my head this should avoid a long lasting deprecation path...but we'll have to find a place to discuss these sort of topics)
  - [ ] think about renaming the gem to light_service. This will require a well thought strategy, if desirable at all.

## Details

Swapping from `ActiveSupport::Deprecation` to `LightService::Deprecation`.

`LightService::Deprecation` is a new built-in class simply built on top of `Logger`.

The only public method is `.warn` - it mimics AS interface.

The logger will log warnings to STDERR with the following format

```
[DEPRECATION] /Users/fuzzy/dev/light-service/lib/light-service/context.rb:106:in `skip_all!': Using skip_all! has been deprecated, please use `skip_remaining!` instead
```

issue.title: [RFC] Closing pull requests while a new build is starting causes failures
issue.body:
Build failures often indicate a fault with the software being built such as compilation or test failures. However, there is a subset of build failures (called *environmental* or *non-verification failures*) that are not expected within a standard application development lifecycle, such as build configuration failures, dependency resolution failures, infrastructure failures, and so on.

**Problem:** One type of environmental failure is due to due to git references being no longer available at the time a build job starts. For example, pull requests are merged shortly before the start of the scheduled build, causing a build failure due to an unfound (because merged) branch. In your project, we detected 1 failure of this type over the May-June timespan. For instance, we found that [Build #973](https://travis-ci.org/adomokos/light-service/builds/693975633) did not pass due to the above issue.

**Solution:** It is generally recommended to wait for the build results before merging a pull request. If you wish to skip builds you may also use the [SKIP CI](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build/#skipping-a-build) tag in your commit message. Additionally, it is also possible to skip builds containing non-code changes as shown in [this example](https://github.com/google/EarlGrey/pull/383/files/3b38a5dea36a88aba42a42931e77a7c5429a1837) and below:

```diff

+ before_install:
+  - |
+      if ! git diff --name-only $TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE | grep -qvE '(.md)|(.png)|(.pdf)|(.html)|^(LICENSE)|^(docs)'
+      then
+        echo "Only doc files were updated, not running the CI."
+        exit
+      fi

```
---
*Disclaimer:* I developed a tool that repairs environmental build failures and I am now evaluating its usefulness for open-source projects.

*Please up/downvote the issue to indicate whether you agree/disagree with the report and the proposed fix.*

issue.title: Implement a built-in, dependency free localization adapter
issue.body:
## Preface

This proposal takes step from the discussion in https://github.com/adomokos/light-service/pull/236.

To the attention of both @adomokos and @gee-forr 

The overall plan in my head, at the moment, is the following

1. decouple light-service from I18n (**this PR**)
  1.1. preserve a basic translation functionality
  1.2 do not break compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n
2. strip out `LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` into its own `light_service-i18n` gem
  2.1 require gem installation to retain full compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n
3. decouple light-service from `ActiveSupport::Deprecation`
  3.1 preserve full functionality through the use of a simple custom logger built on top of `Logger`
4. decouple light-service from `ActiveSupport::Inflector`
  4.1 write a `LightService::Inflector` class responding only to the needed inflection methods (probably `#underscore` and `#pluralize`)
  4.2 `LightService::Inflector` will delegate its capabilities to `dry-inflector` (which is a zero-deps gem)
5. strip out `LightService::Generators` into its own `light_service-rails` gem
6. release light-service 1.0
  6.1 shut out upgrade instructions in changelog, requiring installation of new detached gems in order to retain moved functionalities (in my head this should avoid a long lasting deprecation path...but we'll have to find a place to discuss these sort of topics)
  6.2 think about renaming the gem to `light_service`. This will require a well thought strategy, if desirable at all.

Pictured this out, let's talk about current PR.

## Details

The built-in adapter is trivial and zero-deps.

This PR is thought to be the first step of a two step update concerning translations.

### First step (Current PR)

The gem ships a localization adapter that does not rely on i18n gem. It has not feature parity because it can't interpolate variables.

The gem, when loaded, will check for `I18n` presence into the global space. If it's not present, then it will use the built-in adapter. If it is present, then an alternative `LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` will be automatically used.

`LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` is exactly the same localization adapter shipped previously.

The README is updated to reflect the new scenario.

Keep in mind that, as it stands, i18n gem is required indirectly by light-service as an activesupport dependency, thus it will be automatically used for translations. This means that this PR won't affect any existing implementation.

### Step two (future PR)

`LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` and its specs will be moved into a new `light_service-i18n` gem (or `light_service-translation`).

light-service will stop to automatically choose the translation adapter, always defaulting to the built-in one.  light_service-i18n will instead forcibly configure itself as translation adapter when installed.

### About branches

Alternatively to request to merge on `main`, a new development branch could be created on the original repository and the PRs could be pointed to that branch. Major version bumps could this way be delayed to the future when generators will be migrated to dedicated gem and the current inflector (activesupport) will be changed to something else. This development branch should have a name that represents the overall roadmap of removing activesupport/rails as dependency

issue.title: Refactor `guess_column_separator` logic
issue.body:
I found the original method's logic too prone to
fail even with simple scenarios. E.g., given this
CSV

```
id,description,created_at,updated_at
1,Acquaforte,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
2,Calcografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
3,Cromolitografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
4,Cromotipografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
5,Eliotipia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
```

the guessed separator would be a colon (`:`) because we have only 4 columns separated by 3 commans (`,`), while in values there are 2 date-time-ish strings with 4 total colons (`:`) as hours/minutes/seconds separators.

My assumption here is that if we have headers in file, then the headers alone are the most affordable source of truth regarding the separator, thus we scan for possible separator only in the first line.

If we haven't headers, then we fallback to the original guessing algorithm.

This refactor turns the method from being flaky to be more consistend and predictable. This means that it **should be considered a breaking change** even if proposed as a bugfix.

Thanks for your attention and for your time.

issue.title: [RFC] Closing pull requests while a new build is starting causes failures
issue.body:
Build failures often indicate a fault with the software being built such as compilation or test failures. However, there is a subset of build failures (called *environmental* or *non-verification failures*) that are not expected within a standard application development lifecycle, such as build configuration failures, dependency resolution failures, infrastructure failures, and so on.

**Problem:** One type of environmental failure is due to due to git references being no longer available at the time a build job starts. For example, pull requests are merged shortly before the start of the scheduled build, causing a build failure due to an unfound (because merged) branch. In your project, we detected 1 failure of this type over the May-June timespan. For instance, we found that [Build #973](https://travis-ci.org/adomokos/light-service/builds/693975633) did not pass due to the above issue.

**Solution:** It is generally recommended to wait for the build results before merging a pull request. If you wish to skip builds you may also use the [SKIP CI](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build/#skipping-a-build) tag in your commit message. Additionally, it is also possible to skip builds containing non-code changes as shown in [this example](https://github.com/google/EarlGrey/pull/383/files/3b38a5dea36a88aba42a42931e77a7c5429a1837) and below:

```diff

+ before_install:
+  - |
+      if ! git diff --name-only $TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE | grep -qvE '(.md)|(.png)|(.pdf)|(.html)|^(LICENSE)|^(docs)'
+      then
+        echo "Only doc files were updated, not running the CI."
+        exit
+      fi

```
---
*Disclaimer:* I developed a tool that repairs environmental build failures and I am now evaluating its usefulness for open-source projects.

issue.body:
## Preface

This proposal takes step from the discussion in https://github.com/adomokos/light-service/pull/236.

To the attention of both @adomokos and @gee-forr 

The overall plan in my head, at the moment, is the following

1. decouple light-service from I18n (**this PR**)
  1.1. preserve a basic translation functionality
  1.2 do not break compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n
2. strip out `LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` into its own `light_service-i18n` gem
  2.1 require gem installation to retain full compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n
3. decouple light-service from `ActiveSupport::Deprecation`
  3.1 preserve full functionality through the use of a simple custom logger built on top of `Logger`
4. decouple light-service from `ActiveSupport::Inflector`
  4.1 write a `LightService::Inflector` class responding only to the needed inflection methods (probably `#underscore` and `#pluralize`)
  4.2 `LightService::Inflector` will delegate its capabilities to `dry-inflector` (which is a zero-deps gem)
5. strip out `LightService::Generators` into its own `light_service-rails` gem
6. release light-service 1.0
  6.1 shut out upgrade instructions in changelog, requiring installation of new detached gems in order to retain moved functionalities (in my head this should avoid a long lasting deprecation path...but we'll have to find a place to discuss these sort of topics)
  6.2 think about renaming the gem to `light_service`. This will require a well thought strategy, if desirable at all.

Pictured this out, let's talk about current PR.

## Details

The built-in adapter is trivial and zero-deps.

This PR is thought to be the first step of a two step update concerning translations.

### First step (Current PR)

The gem ships a localization adapter that does not rely on i18n gem. It has not feature parity because it can't interpolate variables.

The gem, when loaded, will check for `I18n` presence into the global space. If it's not present, then it will use the built-in adapter. If it is present, then an alternative `LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` will be automatically used.

`LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` is exactly the same localization adapter shipped previously.

The README is updated to reflect the new scenario.

Keep in mind that, as it stands, i18n gem is required indirectly by light-service as an activesupport dependency, thus it will be automatically used for translations. This means that this PR won't affect any existing implementation.

### Step two (future PR)

`LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` and its specs will be moved into a new `light_service-i18n` gem (or `light_service-translation`).

light-service will stop to automatically choose the translation adapter, always defaulting to the built-in one.  light_service-i18n will instead forcibly configure itself as translation adapter when installed.

### About branches

Alternatively to request to merge on `main`, a new development branch could be created on the original repository and the PRs could be pointed to that branch. Major version bumps could this way be delayed to the future when generators will be migrated to dedicated gem and the current inflector (activesupport) will be changed to something else. This development branch should have a name that represents the overall roadmap of removing activesupport/rails as dependency

issue.title: Refactor `guess_column_separator` logic
issue.body:
I found the original method's logic too prone to
fail even with simple scenarios. E.g., given this
CSV

```
id,description,created_at,updated_at
1,Acquaforte,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
2,Calcografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
3,Cromolitografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
4,Cromotipografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
5,Eliotipia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
```

the guessed separator would be a colon (`:`) because we have only 4 columns separated by 3 commans (`,`), while in values there are 2 date-time-ish strings with 4 total colons (`:`) as hours/minutes/seconds separators.

My assumption here is that if we have headers in file, then the headers alone are the most affordable source of truth regarding the separator, thus we scan for possible separator only in the first line.

If we haven't headers, then we fallback to the original guessing algorithm.

This refactor turns the method from being flaky to be more consistend and predictable. This means that it **should be considered a breaking change** even if proposed as a bugfix.

Thanks for your attention and for your time.

issue.title: [RFC] Closing pull requests while a new build is starting causes failures
issue.body:
Build failures often indicate a fault with the software being built such as compilation or test failures. However, there is a subset of build failures (called *environmental* or *non-verification failures*) that are not expected within a standard application development lifecycle, such as build configuration failures, dependency resolution failures, infrastructure failures, and so on.

**Problem:** One type of environmental failure is due to due to git references being no longer available at the time a build job starts. For example, pull requests are merged shortly before the start of the scheduled build, causing a build failure due to an unfound (because merged) branch. In your project, we detected 1 failure of this type over the May-June timespan. For instance, we found that [Build #973](https://travis-ci.org/adomokos/light-service/builds/693975633) did not pass due to the above issue.

**Solution:** It is generally recommended to wait for the build results before merging a pull request. If you wish to skip builds you may also use the [SKIP CI](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build/#skipping-a-build) tag in your commit message. Additionally, it is also possible to skip builds containing non-code changes as shown in [this example](https://github.com/google/EarlGrey/pull/383/files/3b38a5dea36a88aba42a42931e77a7c5429a1837) and below:

```diff

+ before_install:
+  - |
+      if ! git diff --name-only $TRAVIS_COMMIT_RANGE | grep -qvE '(.md)|(.png)|(.pdf)|(.html)|^(LICENSE)|^(docs)'
+      then
+        echo "Only doc files were updated, not running the CI."
+        exit
+      fi

```
---
*Disclaimer:* I developed a tool that repairs environmental build failures and I am now evaluating its usefulness for open-source projects.

*Please up/downvote the issue to indicate whether you agree/disagree with the report and the proposed fix.*

issue.title: Implement a built-in, dependency free localization adapter
issue.body:
## Preface

This proposal takes step from the discussion in https://github.com/adomokos/light-service/pull/236.

To the attention of both @adomokos and @gee-forr 

The overall plan in my head, at the moment, is the following

1. decouple light-service from I18n (**this PR**)
  1.1. preserve a basic translation functionality
  1.2 do not break compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n
2. strip out `LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` into its own `light_service-i18n` gem
  2.1 require gem installation to retain full compatibility with existing implementations relying on I18n
3. decouple light-service from `ActiveSupport::Deprecation`
  3.1 preserve full functionality through the use of a simple custom logger built on top of `Logger`
4. decouple light-service from `ActiveSupport::Inflector`
  4.1 write a `LightService::Inflector` class responding only to the needed inflection methods (probably `#underscore` and `#pluralize`)
  4.2 `LightService::Inflector` will delegate its capabilities to `dry-inflector` (which is a zero-deps gem)
5. strip out `LightService::Generators` into its own `light_service-rails` gem
6. release light-service 1.0
  6.1 shut out upgrade instructions in changelog, requiring installation of new detached gems in order to retain moved functionalities (in my head this should avoid a long lasting deprecation path...but we'll have to find a place to discuss these sort of topics)
  6.2 think about renaming the gem to `light_service`. This will require a well thought strategy, if desirable at all.

Pictured this out, let's talk about current PR.

## Details

The built-in adapter is trivial and zero-deps.

This PR is thought to be the first step of a two step update concerning translations.

### First step (Current PR)

The gem ships a localization adapter that does not rely on i18n gem. It has not feature parity because it can't interpolate variables.

The gem, when loaded, will check for `I18n` presence into the global space. If it's not present, then it will use the built-in adapter. If it is present, then an alternative `LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` will be automatically used.

`LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` is exactly the same localization adapter shipped previously.

The README is updated to reflect the new scenario.

Keep in mind that, as it stands, i18n gem is required indirectly by light-service as an activesupport dependency, thus it will be automatically used for translations. This means that this PR won't affect any existing implementation.

### Step two (future PR)

`LightService::I18n::LocalizationAdapter` and its specs will be moved into a new `light_service-i18n` gem (or `light_service-translation`).

light-service will stop to automatically choose the translation adapter, always defaulting to the built-in one.  light_service-i18n will instead forcibly configure itself as translation adapter when installed.

### About branches

Alternatively to request to merge on `main`, a new development branch could be created on the original repository and the PRs could be pointed to that branch. Major version bumps could this way be delayed to the future when generators will be migrated to dedicated gem and the current inflector (activesupport) will be changed to something else. This development branch should have a name that represents the overall roadmap of removing activesupport/rails as dependency

issue.body:
I found the original method's logic too prone to
fail even with simple scenarios. E.g., given this
CSV

```
id,description,created_at,updated_at
1,Acquaforte,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
2,Calcografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
3,Cromolitografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
4,Cromotipografia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
5,Eliotipia,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC,2022-10-04 16:00:47 UTC
```

the guessed separator would be a colon (`:`) because we have only 4 columns separated by 3 commans (`,`), while in values there are 2 date-time-ish strings with 4 total colons (`:`) as hours/minutes/seconds separators.

My assumption here is that if we have headers in file, then the headers alone are the most affordable source of truth regarding the separator, thus we scan for possible separator only in the first line.

If we haven't headers, then we fallback to the original guessing algorithm.

This refactor turns the method from being flaky to be more consistend and predictable. This means that it **should be considered a breaking change** even if proposed as a bugfix.

Thanks for your attention and for your time.

comment.body:
@martin-josef as far as your report is a really complete one, it's hard to track it down as a bug.

It's not reproducible, as you reported. What we probably have is a behavior in Wordmove that your current hosting provider dislikes.

I can't elaborate a solution but I have a previous experience to share; Wordmove has a somewhat defective behavior when working w/ DB: it makes a lot of subsequent connections. Sometimes hosting providers set a throttle limit in order to protect themselves from ddos-like attempts and this limit could happen to resolve into a refute to auth the user.

One desperate try to do in order to verify this assumption is to add these configs to the specific host into your ssh config

```
Host example.com
  ControlMaster auto
  ControlPath /tmp/master-%r@%h:%p
  [...]
```

then in one terminal open an SSH connection to the host and in another terminal run `wordmove pull -e production -d`. This way you should force SSH client to reuse a single connection through a local socket (don't know if it's actually a socket, but at least it has a similar concept).

Is this a fix? It is not for sure. It's more of a troubleshooting/possible workaround/reproduction path, but that's all I have on the table.
